question_text: Summarize the call with Ivy Lane about expansion and metrics, and provide next steps
answer_text:
*Meeting Summary (Ivy Lane (Valvoline))*

*Purpose*
Align on metrics, test design, and rollout plan for a 10-store pilot of the “pit crew” speed technology to measure impact on service speed and overall satisfaction.

*Key Topics*
• Metrics: OSAT (overall satisfaction) and speed-of-service; average service duration  
• Measurement approach: sequential pre/post vs YoY; sample size limits; aggregate across 10 stores  
• Targets: 3-point increases (OSAT, speed); 10% improvement in service duration; success criteria nuance  
• Test design: three cells (Tech+Mgmt, Mgmt-only, Control); data source limitations (POS timing, survey bias)  
• Installation/ops: login stability (QR), need for app-based login/TV lockdown; monitoring TVs; minimizing on-site setup time

*Decisions & Outcomes*
• Use sequential measurement (prefer ~90 days pre and 90 days post) rather than YoY  
• Aggregate CSAT across the 10-store cohort (not per-store) due to low per-store survey counts  
• Targets: ≥3-point increase for OSAT and speed; ≥10% reduction in average service duration  
• Count as success if speed improves significantly even if OSAT is flat (given tool’s focus on speed)  
• Proceed with 10-store expansion despite no TV lockdown; actively monitor TV/login status  
• Add a Mgmt-only test cell (no tech) plus Control alongside Tech+Mgmt to isolate tech impact (Karen’s team to own)  
• QR code login appears to have resolved prior login issues at the problem store

*Open Questions*
• Finalize measurement windows: 30-day stabilization + 60-day measurement vs full 90/90 pre/post  
• How to compare average service duration in Mgmt-only cell without objective timing; guardrails against gaming; reliance on CSAT vs POS  
• Is there automated alerting when TVs/logins go offline (beyond manual monitoring)?  
• Timeline for app-based login and TV lockdown/external appliance; criteria for scaling beyond 10 without them  
• Confirm store selection and start dates per cell; ownership of contests/visibility setup

_Source: PitCrew Meeting Transcripts_

question_text:
One of our customers, Ivy Lane, is considering expansion beyond the 2 store pilot we did with them. They want to expand to 10 stores, and use this to more closely evaluate the ROI of PitCrew before deciding whether they deploy to the rest of their footprint (about 75 total stores). For this 10 store expansion, it'll be critical that we are aligned on which metrics we are evaluating, so that we can have an objective measure of success. I want to create a draft plan for expansion which includes (a) which key metrics we'll be evaluating, (b) how we'll measure/evaluate them, and (c) what % improvement we're targeting for each metric. I do not have confidence in the customer creating this themselves, so I believe we need to create a draft and have them react to it.

Create a document that details success measures for this 10 store expansion. Here is what I'm thinking:
• One of the metrics is customer satisfaction. They already measure this via surveys that customers take. To measure this, we would compare the same calendar period from the year prior (to reduce extraneous variables like seasonality). Happier customers should lead to more business over time, i.e. more repeat customers, though we won't be able to prove that necessarily during this expansion
    ◦ Let's target a 1% improvement (e.g. if their overall satisfaction score was 65%, we bump it to 66%)
• The other metric is average service duration. This will ultimately translate into one or both of the following: (1) more revenue, because during periods of high demand more invoices can be completed with the same team meaning more money, and you lose fewer customers to abandonments from too long wait times, and (2) labor cost savings, because you can accomplish the same number of invoices with a smaller team
    ◦ Measuring this is a bit more tricky, since Ivy Lane doesn't have any pre-existing data for comparison. So I think that for each store, the first 2 weeks after we install PitCrew, we collect a baseline of data. Then we install the TV dashboards in the bays and give access to the store managers. That way we can compare the average service duration before and after
    ◦ Let's target a 10% improvement (e.g. if the average service duration is 20 minutes, we improve by 2 minutes)
• For each metric, explain:
    ◦ Why it matters / the business value (lean on the value props of PitCrew here to inform your writing)
    ◦ How we will measure it plus why we recommend this methodology
    ◦ The target goal
• Let's place the total evaluation timeline, for each store, at minimum 60 days, starting from when PitCrew is first installed. 15 days of baseline collection then 45 days of comparison for improvement
    ◦ We should also include a draft roll out schedule. Assume 10 total stores. They already have 2 deployed, so 8 new deployments. Let's assume 4 the first month and 4 the second month. Assume it takes 15 days to ship server, and do set up and configuration before we're ready to start collecting baseline. So each store is total of ~90 days. Given 4 stores won't be deployed til the second month, that means that this whole thing would run for about 120 days aka  months
• In addition, one concern that the customer has voiced is that the roll out of the pilot stores took a lot of time/effort from one of their key people to support, so they're concerned about the maintenance burden of rolling out additional stores. As such, it's important that we mention this explicitly and how we plan to mitigate the burden on them. I'm not sure how we would measure this. Maybe we add another success criterion that's: by the 10th store, PitCrew installation can be performed entirely by the on-site crew with no on-site travel required from Kou (the key person mentioned) or from Leverege.
    ◦ We should also cover the process for rolling out a new store. Basically we ship them a server, someone onsite plugs it into their NVR via ethernet, then once we access the local cameras we give feedback on adjustments to camera angles. They also physically install at least one TV in the bay in a place where everyone can see it.
Before you attempt, do you have any questions? Also tell me how you think this should be structured, before you create the document, so I can give you early feedback before you do the work
answer_text:
Here is the proposed structure for the document detailing success measures for the Ivy Lane 10-store expansion:

**1. Document Title:** Ivy Lane 10-Store Expansion: Proposed Success Measures & Rollout Plan

**2. Introduction:**
    *   Briefly state the purpose: to align on key metrics, measurement methodologies, and target improvements for the 10-store PitCrew expansion, serving as an objective evaluation for future deployment decisions.

**3. Key Success Metrics & Targets:**
    *   **Metric 1: Customer Satisfaction**
        *   **Why it matters / Business Value:** Explain how improved customer satisfaction enhances customer experience and retention, leading to repeat business and loyalty.
        *   **How we will measure it and why this methodology is recommended:** Detail the use of existing customer surveys, comparing data from the same calendar period year-over-year to account for seasonality.
        *   **Target Goal:** State the 1% improvement target.
    *   **Metric 2: Average Service Duration**
        *   **Why it matters / Business Value:** Explain how reduced service duration translates into increased service speed and throughput capacity, enabling more revenue capture during peak demand and potential labor cost savings through improved unit economics.
        *   **How we will measure it and why this methodology is recommended:** Describe the 15-day baseline data collection post-installation, followed by the activation of TV dashboards and manager access for comparison, allowing for a clear before-and-after assessment for each store.
        *   **Target Goal:** State the 10% improvement target.
    *   **Metric 3: Rollout Efficiency**
        *   **Why it matters / Business Value:** Address Ivy Lane's concern regarding the burden of rollout, emphasizing the goal of manager enablement and reduced operational friction for future deployments.
        *   **How we will measure it and why this methodology is recommended:** Define the success criterion of achieving self-sufficient installation by the 10th store, eliminating the need for external on-site support.
        *   **Target Goal:** State the target: by the 10th store, PitCrew installation can be performed entirely by the on-site crew with no on-site travel required from Kou or from Leverege.

**4. Overall Evaluation Timeline:**
    *   Detail the minimum 60-day evaluation period per store (15 days for baseline collection, 45 days for improvement comparison) commencing from PitCrew installation.

**5. Draft Rollout Schedule:**
    *   Outline the 15-day pre-baseline setup phase (server shipment, setup, configuration).
    *   Present the deployment plan: 4 new stores in Month 1, 4 new stores in Month 2.
    *   Calculate the total estimated duration for the entire 10-store expansion evaluation (approximately 120 days / 4 months).

**6. New Store Rollout Process:**
    *   Describe the step-by-step process for deploying PitCrew at a new location: server shipment, on-site NVR connection, camera angle feedback, and TV dashboard installation.

This structure directly addresses all your requirements and integrates your proposed points precisely.

_Source: Generated by GPT-4o_

answer_text:
I understand the request. Here is how I propose to structure the document detailing the success measures for Ivy Lane's 10-store expansion:

## Draft Plan for Ivy Lane 10-Store Expansion: Success Measures

### Introduction
This section will set the stage, briefly explaining the purpose of this document: to establish clear, objective metrics and measurement methodologies for evaluating the success of PitCrew's expansion across 10 Ivy Lane locations. It will emphasize that this evaluation is critical for assessing the Return on Investment (ROI) and informing future decisions regarding a full-footprint deployment across Ivy Lane's remaining stores.

### Overall Evaluation Timeline and Phased Rollout
This section will detail the timeline for each individual store's evaluation, including baseline collection and improvement measurement periods. It will also outline the phased rollout schedule for the 8 new stores, leading to the overall project duration.

### Key Success Metrics and Target Goals
This will be the core of the document, with a dedicated subsection for each key metric:

#### Customer Satisfaction
*   **Why This Metric Matters:** Explain the business value, linking it to PitCrew's "Customer Experience & Retention" value theme and the user's insight that happier customers lead to more repeat business.
*   **Measurement Methodology:** Describe how Ivy Lane's existing survey data will be used, specifying the year-over-year comparison to account for seasonality.
*   **Target Goal:** State the 1% improvement target.

#### Average Service Duration
*   **Why This Metric Matters:** Explain the business value, connecting it to PitCrew's "Service Speed & Throughput Capacity" and "Unit Economics & Capacity Planning" value themes. Detail how reduced duration translates to increased revenue (more invoices, fewer abandonments) and potential labor cost savings.
*   **Measurement Methodology:** Detail the proposed baseline collection period (first 15 days post-install) and the subsequent comparison period (45 days) after TV dashboards and manager access are enabled, explaining why this "before and after" approach is recommended given Ivy Lane's current data.
*   **Target Goal:** State the 10% improvement target.

### Streamlining PitCrew Deployment and Mitigating Customer Burden
This section will directly address Ivy Lane's concern regarding the effort involved in previous deployments.

#### New Store Rollout Process
This subsection will clearly outline the step-by-step process for deploying PitCrew in a new store, from server shipment to camera adjustments and TV installation, emphasizing the roles of both Leverege and Ivy Lane's on-site team.

#### Deployment Efficiency Success Criterion
This subsection will introduce a specific, measurable success criterion related to the ease and independence of future deployments, explicitly stating the goal for on-site teams to perform installations without external travel support by the 10th store.

### Next Steps
This concluding section will propose a next step, such as a meeting to review and finalize this proposed plan.

This structure is comprehensive, directly addresses all your points, and allows for the integration of PitCrew's value propositions and terminology as instructed. I will ensure to write in full paragraphs with specific details and use markdown formatting.

_Source: Generated by GPT-4o_

question_text: Ok, go ahead and create the document
answer_text:
## Draft Plan for Ivy Lane 10-Store Expansion: Success Measures

### Introduction

Ivy Lane is considering a significant expansion of PitCrew beyond the initial two-store pilot to an additional ten locations. This expansion is a critical step in evaluating the tangible return on investment (ROI) that PitCrew delivers before a potential full-footprint deployment across Ivy Lane's approximately 75 stores. To ensure an objective and data-driven assessment, this document outlines the key metrics we propose to evaluate, the methodologies for measurement, and the target improvements for each. This plan is designed to provide clear success criteria and a structured approach for the upcoming 10-store expansion.

### Key Success Measures

#### 1. Customer Satisfaction (CSAT)

*   **Why it Matters / Business Value:**
    Customer satisfaction is a cornerstone of long-term business success, directly impacting customer retention and loyalty. PitCrew significantly contributes to an improved customer experience by providing real-time visibility into operations, which helps ensure every customer is greeted promptly, promise times are accurate, and overall wait times are reduced. When customers feel valued and their time is respected, repeat visits increase, and positive word-of-mouth enhances brand reputation. Happy customers are more likely to become loyal patrons, driving sustained business growth and strengthening Unit Economics & Capacity Planning by ensuring consistent demand.

*   **How We Will Measure It:**
    We will leverage Ivy Lane's existing customer survey data, which is already collected to measure customer satisfaction. Our methodology will involve comparing the average customer satisfaction scores from the ten PitCrew-enabled stores during the evaluation period against the scores from the *same calendar period in the previous year* (pre-PitCrew installation). We recommend this approach to minimize the impact of extraneous variables such as seasonality or broader market trends, providing a more accurate assessment of PitCrew's direct influence on customer sentiment.

*   **Target Goal:**
    We aim for a **1% improvement** in the overall customer satisfaction score. For example, if a store's average satisfaction score was 65%, our target would be an increase to 66%.

#### 2. Average Service Duration

*   **Why it Matters / Business Value:**
    Average service duration is a critical indicator of operational efficiency and directly impacts both revenue potential and labor costs, aligning with PitCrew's value themes of Service Speed & Throughput Capacity and Unit Economics & Capacity Planning. A reduction in service duration translates into two primary benefits: (1) **Increased Revenue:** During periods of high demand, faster service allows more vehicles to be processed with the same team, capturing additional revenue and reducing customer abandonments due to long wait times. (2) **Labor Cost Savings:** The same volume of invoices can be completed with a smaller team, optimizing labor allocation and reducing operational expenses. PitCrew enables this by surfacing bottlenecks, speeding up intake processes, and ensuring work moves efficiently from bay to bay, maximizing throughput without requiring additional bays or headcount.

*   **How We Will Measure It:**
    Given that Ivy Lane may not have pre-existing granular data for direct historical comparison, our measurement methodology will establish a clear "before and after" within the same operational context. For each of the ten expansion stores, we will collect a **15-day baseline of average service duration** immediately following PitCrew installation but *before* the TV dashboards are activated and store managers are given full access to the system. Following this baseline period, we will activate the TV dashboards and provide manager access, then compare the average service duration from the subsequent **45 days** of active PitCrew utilization against the established baseline. This approach allows us to isolate the impact of PitCrew's real-time visibility and coaching tools.

*   **Target Goal:**
    We aim for a **10% improvement** in average service duration. For instance, if the initial average service duration is 20 minutes, our target is to reduce it by 2 minutes, bringing it down to 18 minutes.

### Evaluation Timeline and Rollout Schedule

#### Overall Evaluation Timeline

For each individual store, the evaluation timeline will span a minimum of **60 days** from the initial PitCrew installation. This period is broken down into:
*   **15 days** for baseline data collection immediately post-installation.
*   **45 days** for the comparison period, during which PitCrew's tools are actively used to drive improvement.

Considering the phased rollout across multiple stores, the entire project, from the first store's installation to the completion of the last store's 60-day evaluation, is anticipated to run for approximately **120 days (four months)**.

#### Draft Rollout Schedule (8 New Stores)

The rollout for the 8 new stores will be phased to allow for focused support and smooth integration:

*   **Deployment Process (Per Store):**
    1.  **Server Shipment:** PitCrew will ship the necessary server hardware to the Ivy Lane store location.
    2.  **On-site Setup:** The on-site store crew will plug the server into their existing Network Video Recorder (NVR) via Ethernet.
    3.  **Remote Camera Configuration:** Once connected, Leverege will remotely access the local cameras and provide feedback to the on-site crew on any necessary adjustments to camera angles to ensure optimal data capture.
    4.  **TV Dashboard Installation:** The on-site crew will physically install at least one TV dashboard in a visible location within the service bay area for real-time operational feedback.
    5.  **Baseline Data Collection:** After camera angles are optimized and the TV is installed, a 15-day period for baseline data collection will commence.
    6.  **Active PitCrew Use:** Following the baseline, TV dashboards will be activated and full manager access granted, initiating the 45-day improvement comparison period.

*   **Phased Deployment Schedule:**
    *   **Month 1:** Four new stores will begin their PitCrew deployment process. Allowing for approximately 15 days for shipping, setup, and configuration before baseline collection begins, these stores will then enter their 60-day evaluation period.
    *   **Month 2:** The remaining four new stores will begin their PitCrew deployment process, following the same 15-day setup and 60-day evaluation cycle.

This staggered approach ensures that while individual store evaluations are 60 days, the full project duration extends to approximately 120 days to accommodate the sequential deployment and complete evaluation for all ten new locations.

### Mitigating Deployment Burden and Streamlining Rollout

Ivy Lane has expressed a valid concern regarding the time and effort required from key personnel, such as Kou, during the initial pilot rollout. PitCrew is fully committed to addressing this by significantly streamlining the deployment process for this 10-store expansion, aiming to minimize the internal burden on Ivy Lane's team.

Our strategy for mitigating this burden includes:
*   **Standardized, Self-Service Installation:** The described rollout process (server shipment, on-site plug-in, remote camera adjustment guidance, on-site TV installation) is intentionally designed to be as self-sufficient as possible for the local store crew. We will provide comprehensive, clear instructions and dedicated remote support from Leverege throughout each step.
*   **Reduced Need for On-Site Travel:** For this expansion, our primary objective is to dramatically reduce, and ideally eliminate, the necessity for on-site travel from either Leverege personnel or Ivy Lane's central team, including Kou. We believe that with our refined process and remote support capabilities, most, if not all, installation and configuration tasks can be managed effectively from a distance.
*   **Success Criterion for Deployment Efficiency:** To objectively measure our success in reducing the deployment burden, we propose a specific criterion: **by the 10th store installation, PitCrew can be deployed and configured entirely by the on-site store crew with absolutely no on-site travel required from Kou or from Leverege personnel.** Achieving this will be a key indicator of our ability to scale PitCrew efficiently and cost-effectively across Ivy Lane's entire footprint in the future, demonstrating a truly streamlined and manageable rollout process.

_Source: Generated by GPT-4o_

question_text: what is the update on Allied Lube
answer_text:
_Based on the most recent Allied Lube (Jiffy Lube) meeting (Jan 28, 2026):_

The current update on Allied Lube is that the Leverege team is working with Bob Seidmeyer to identify the right pilot store and validate the setup, including camera angles and bandwidth. Once validation is complete, a server will be shipped to the pilot store, and access to the system will be set up for key personnel like the owner and VP of operations. A kickoff meeting will then be scheduled to officially start the 60-day free pilot.

_Corey will follow up with you and we can get working with you on identifying the right pilot store and doing some validation... Once we feel good about all that stuff, we'll ship you a server and kick things off._

_Source: PitCrew Meeting Transcripts (synthesized by Gemini 2.5 Flash)_
